elements.title: Progressive Disclosure as Graduated Renunciation
elements.problem: The host journey demands escalating surrenders of private information -- identity at onboarding, property details at listing creation, financial expectations at pricing. But the platform currently presents these demands without regard for the cumulative psychological cost. Freud identifies that 'civilization is built up on renunciation of instinctual gratifications' and that this 'cultural privation dominates the whole field of social relations.' The information architecture problem is: what information to request at each phase, and what to withhold requesting until later, so that each disclosure feels proportional to the value already received. When the platform asks for too much too early (photos before the host has seen demand signals, financial details before the host understands the guarantee), it triggers what Freud calls the 'antagonism against which all civilization has to fight' -- the host's instinctual revolt against an information extraction that feels unjustified.
elements.solution: Structure the information request sequence so that every disclosure demanded is preceded by a value disclosure from the platform. Discovery reveals market demand data (no host information requested). Evaluation reveals the agent and payment guarantee (only basic contact requested). Onboarding reveals the agent relationship and matched guest demand (identity verification requested). Listing creation reveals comparable earnings and guest interest signals (property details and photos requested). Each tier of the information hierarchy follows the same pattern: the platform discloses civilizational value first, then the host discloses instinctual territory. The ratio should be approximately 2:1 -- two pieces of platform value for every one piece of host disclosure. This mirrors Freud's graduated renunciation: the host surrenders incrementally, and each surrender is 'made good economically' by prior evidence that the civilizational contract pays.

evidence.quote: Any flow that requires users to give information before seeing results will lose most of them. Show something useful first. Offer to refine after.
evidence.insight: Rod's 'value before the ask' principle is the information architecture translation of Freud's economic law of renunciation: the host will not disclose private information (instinctual territory) unless the platform has first demonstrated that prior disclosures produced tangible value. The information hierarchy must enforce this sequencing at every level.

evidence.quote: It is impossible to ignore the extent to which civilization is built up on renunciation of instinctual gratifications... This 'cultural privation' dominates the whole field of social relations between human beings; we know already that it is the cause of the antagonism against which all civilization has to fight.
evidence.insight: Every piece of information the platform requests from the host is a form of cultural privation -- the host gives up privacy, autonomy, or intimacy in exchange for marketplace participation. Information architecture must sequence these privations so the antagonism is managed rather than provoked.

evidence.quote: If the deprivation is not made good economically, one may be certain of producing serious disorders.
evidence.insight: Freud's warning applies directly: if the platform requests information (imposes deprivation) without simultaneously delivering value (economic remedy), the host will develop 'serious disorders' -- abandonment, distrust, negative word-of-mouth. The information hierarchy must pair every request with a preceding reward.

elements.hierarchy_principle: Primary. This is the governing principle for the entire information architecture -- all other elements depend on getting the disclosure sequence right. Information that reveals civilizational value (demand data, guarantees, agent identity) is primary. Information that requests instinctual surrender (identity, property details, photos) is secondary and must always follow primary disclosures.
elements.disclosure_pattern: Phase-gated, value-led. Discovery: platform discloses demand signals, requests nothing. Evaluation: platform discloses payment guarantee and agent, requests contact info. Onboarding: platform discloses matched demand and agent relationship, requests identity verification. Listing creation: platform discloses comparable earnings and guest interest, requests property details and photos. Never two consecutive requests without an intervening value delivery.
elements.cognitive_load_constraint: Each phase transition should present no more than one new category of requested information. The host should never face simultaneous requests for identity AND property details AND pricing in the same interaction. Limit to one disclosure type per screen or interaction segment.
exclude: Fee structure details before the host has seen potential earnings
Full terms of service before the host has spoken with an agent
Guest vetting criteria before the host has a live listing
Platform comparison data that frames the host's situation as a problem rather than an opportunity

elements.title: Bidirectional Protection Framing for All Platform Rules
elements.problem: The platform enforces rules at multiple touchpoints: confirmation dialogs, approval flows, date change restrictions, review requirements. The host experiences these as bureaucratic constraints on their autonomy -- Freud's 'cultural privation' applied to action rather than information. But the host does not see the bidirectional nature of these constraints. When the platform says 'Date changes require both parties to agree,' the host hears 'I cannot change dates without permission.' They do not automatically hear 'The guest also cannot change dates without my permission.' Freud identifies that 'the first requisite of culture is justice -- the assurance that a law once made will not be broken in favour of any individual.' But justice is only perceived as justice when both sides of the constraint are visible. One-sided constraint information produces the experience of oppression, not protection.
elements.solution: Every rule, restriction, or confirmation in the information architecture must surface both sides of the constraint simultaneously. The information template for any platform-enforced rule is: [What you cannot do unilaterally] + [What the other party also cannot do unilaterally] + [What this protects for you]. For example: 'Date changes require mutual agreement. This means the guest cannot change your scheduled stays without your approval, and you cannot change theirs without their agreement. Both of you are protected from unexpected disruptions.' The bidirectional frame transforms the information from a restriction notice into a protection notice. The scan order places the protection first and the restriction second, so the host's initial impression (Freud's automatic assessment, analogous to L1's System 1 gate) is safety rather than constraint.

evidence.quote: The first requisite of culture, therefore, is justice -- that is, the assurance that a law once made will not be broken in favour of any individual.
evidence.insight: Platform rules are Freud's 'law.' But a law perceived as one-sided feels unjust regardless of its actual fairness. The information architecture must present every rule as a bidirectional guarantee: the host sees both what they cannot do and what the guest cannot do, making the justice of the constraint self-evident.

evidence.quote: The park analogy holds -- you check availability before committing. A message action reduces abandonment when someone isn't ready for a proposal. Having the option is better than having no action at all.
evidence.insight: The messaging step is a low-stakes civilizational mediation: it lets both parties assess each other informally before the formal structure (proposal) is invoked. The information architecture should frame every intermediate step as protection for the host, not process for the platform.

evidence.quote: Civilization expects to prevent the worst atrocities of brutal violence by taking upon itself the right to employ violence against criminals, but the law is not able to lay hands on the more discreet and subtle forms in which human aggressions are expressed.
evidence.insight: The platform's structured rituals (arrival notifications, cleaning photos, date change approvals) address the subtle aggressions that no formal rule can prevent: lateness, messiness, broken communication promises. The information architecture must frame these mechanisms as addressing real risks the host cares about.

elements.hierarchy_principle: Primary for all rule and constraint surfaces. Whenever the platform enforces a restriction, the bidirectional protection frame takes hierarchical precedence over the procedural explanation. The host sees 'what this protects' before 'what this requires.'
elements.disclosure_pattern: At the point of enforcement, not in advance. Bidirectional framing should appear inline at the exact moment the host encounters the constraint (when they attempt a date change, when they receive a confirmation dialog), not in a separate policy document. The protection information is contextual: it only matters when the constraint is felt.
elements.cognitive_load_constraint: Each bidirectional frame should be expressible in two sentences maximum: one sentence for the reciprocal constraint, one sentence for the protection it provides. No legal language. No links to policy pages. The protection must be immediately legible without navigation.
exclude: One-sided constraint language ('You must wait for approval')
Legal or contractual framing ('Per Section 4.2 of the Terms of Service')
Punitive framing ('Failure to comply will result in...')
Policy links that require the host to leave the current context

elements.title: Stranger Threat Reduction Through Civilizational Compliance Signals
elements.problem: Freud's Ch V states that 'men are not gentle, friendly creatures wishing for love' but carry 'a powerful measure of desire for aggression.' For the host reviewing a guest proposal, this manifests as instinctual distrust of the stranger seeking entry to their private space. The information architecture challenge is: what information about the guest must be surfaced, in what order, and at what granularity, to reduce the host's instinctual threat response before it crystallizes into rejection or inaction. Currently, guest information is distributed across multiple surfaces -- profile page, proposal body, reviews section, verification badges. The host must assemble a threat assessment from scattered signals, which is cognitively expensive and defaults to distrust when any signal is missing or requires navigation to find.

evidence.quote: The bit of truth behind all this -- one so eagerly denied -- is that men are not gentle, friendly creatures wishing for love... but that a powerful measure of desire for aggression has to be reckoned as part of their instinctual endowment. The result is that their neighbour is to them not only a possible helper or sexual object, but also a temptation to them to gratify their aggressiveness on him.
evidence.insight: Every guest proposal arrives carrying Freud's double valence: the guest is simultaneously a 'possible helper' (income source) and an instinctual threat (stranger in the host's space). The information architecture must resolve this ambiguity in favor of the helper reading by presenting civilizational compliance evidence before the host's instinct defaults to threat.

evidence.quote: A well-structured proposal -- clear dates, schedule, pricing, intent -- activates the host to respond. A vague or incomplete one creates friction. Stories that push toward more structured, pre-populated proposal forms aren't just about UX, they're about making the cross-activation moment as clean as possible.
evidence.insight: Proposal structure is itself an information architecture decision. The structure of the proposal -- what fields are required, what order they appear in, what is pre-populated vs. guest-entered -- determines whether the host's first impression is 'organized person following the rules' or 'unknown stranger with unclear intentions.'

evidence.quote: When someone who's already used Split Lease applies to a host who's never had a guest, that guest's reputation does the selling. Their history, their reviews, their familiarity with how things work -- it all reduces the host's anxiety.
evidence.insight: Prior civilizational participation (completed leases, reviews given/received, verification status) is the strongest instinct-reduction signal. The information architecture must place this evidence at the top of the proposal's scan order, before terms and dates, because the host's willingness to read terms depends on first resolving the stranger-threat question.

elements.solution: Consolidate all guest trust signals into a single, scannable surface embedded within the proposal view itself. The information hierarchy for a guest proposal should follow the host's natural decision tree: (1) Is this person safe? (verification status, completed leases, review summary). (2) Is this person compatible? (stated reason for stay, work schedule, duration intent). (3) Are the terms acceptable? (dates, pricing, lease style). (4) What do I do next? (accept, counter, decline, message). The current architecture puts terms first and trust second. The Freud lens inverts this: trust must precede terms because the host will not evaluate terms from a stranger they have not yet assessed as non-threatening. Surface the guest's civilizational compliance evidence -- ID verification, completed leases count, average review rating, stated purpose -- as the first information block, before any proposal details.
elements.hierarchy_principle: Primary: civilizational compliance signals (verification, history, reviews). Secondary: compatibility signals (reason for stay, schedule, duration). Tertiary: transactional terms (dates, pricing, lease style). This inverts the typical form-first architecture because Freud's insight demands that the stranger-threat question be resolved before the host can engage with terms rationally.
elements.disclosure_pattern: All trust-relevant information presented simultaneously in the first scan zone of the proposal view. No navigation required. The host should be able to resolve the 'is this person safe?' question within 3 seconds of opening a proposal. Terms and details are revealed in the second scan zone, after trust has been established.
elements.cognitive_load_constraint: The trust block should contain no more than 5 data points: verification status (icon), completed leases (number), review rating (score), member since (date), stated purpose (one sentence). Each point should be interpretable without reading -- icons, numbers, and visual indicators rather than paragraphs. Total cognitive processing time for the trust block: under 3 seconds.
exclude: Raw review text in the proposal view (link to full reviews, but do not embed lengthy text)
Guest financial details (income, employment) unless directly relevant to lease qualification
Platform-internal scores or ratings that the guest cannot see or influence
Any trust signal that requires the host to navigate away from the proposal view

elements.title: Urgency-First Dashboard as Civilizational Order System
elements.problem: Freud identifies order as 'a kind of repetition-compulsion by which it is ordained once for all when, where and how a thing shall be done so that on every similar occasion doubt and hesitation shall be avoided.' The host dashboard is the primary surface where the host encounters the platform's order -- or its disorder. When the dashboard presents information without a clear urgency hierarchy (mixing completed tasks with pending ones, surfacing inactive listings alongside urgent proposals, showing old messages next to new notifications), it violates Freud's order principle and produces the anxiety it should be reducing. The user stories analysis confirms this: 'Urgency should surface first on the dashboard. Unread proposals, pending actions, incomplete listings -- that's what a host needs to see the moment they log in.' The information architecture challenge is to create a dashboard hierarchy that functions as the platform's civilizational order: predictable, scannable, and anxiety-reducing.

evidence.quote: Unread proposals, pending actions, incomplete listings -- that's what a host needs to see the moment they log in. Everything else is secondary to what's waiting for them right now.
evidence.insight: Rod's urgency-first principle maps directly to Freud's order: the dashboard should impose a clear hierarchy that eliminates the host's need to search for what requires attention. The information architecture must sort by action-required status, not by recency or category.

evidence.quote: Order is a kind of repetition-compulsion by which it is ordained once for all when, where and how a thing shall be done so that on every similar occasion doubt and hesitation shall be avoided. The benefits of order are incontestable: it enables us to use space and time to the best advantage, while saving expenditure of mental energy.
evidence.insight: The dashboard is where the host expends or conserves mental energy. An ordered dashboard that surfaces urgent items first, completed items second, and informational items third saves the mental energy that a disordered dashboard wastes on scanning, sorting, and worrying about what was missed.

evidence.quote: Hosts need to know what's unfinished before a listing goes live. A visible progress indicator on the listing card creates just enough friction to get them to finish -- without being in the way.
evidence.insight: Completion indicators are a form of Freudian order applied to individual items: they impose a clear binary (finished/unfinished) that eliminates the host's doubt about what remains. The information architecture extends this principle from listing cards to the entire dashboard: every item should carry a clear action-status signal.

elements.solution: Structure the dashboard information hierarchy into three tiers, consistently ordered across every login: (1) Action Required: unread proposals, pending approvals, incomplete listings, unacknowledged date changes. These appear at the top with visual urgency indicators (not alarm-red, but distinct from ambient information -- amber or high-contrast). Each item shows the specific action needed and the consequence of inaction (e.g., 'Proposal expires in 48 hours'). (2) Status Updates: active lease summaries, recent cleaning photo submissions, review notifications, payment confirmations. These appear in the middle zone and are informational -- they reduce anxiety by confirming the civilizational order is holding, but they do not require action. (3) Background Information: earnings summaries, host milestones, platform announcements, feature updates. These appear at the bottom and are available but not prominent. The key structural rule: the dashboard layout must be identical every time the host visits. Freud's repetition-compulsion means the host should know exactly where to look for urgent items without learning a new layout each time.
elements.hierarchy_principle: Primary: action-required items (proposals, approvals, incomplete tasks). Secondary: status confirmation items (active lease health, payment confirmations, cleaning photos). Tertiary: informational items (earnings, milestones, platform news). This hierarchy reflects Freud's insight that order saves mental energy -- the host should expend zero cognitive effort determining what needs their attention.
elements.disclosure_pattern: Static layout, dynamic content. The three tiers occupy fixed positions on every dashboard view. Content within each tier is sorted by urgency (expiration deadline) and recency. New items are visually distinct from seen items. The dashboard never rearranges its structure; only the items within each tier change. This predictability is the digital equivalent of Freud's order: 'ordained once for all when, where and how.'
elements.cognitive_load_constraint: The Action Required tier should display no more than 5 items simultaneously. If more than 5 actions are pending, show the 5 most urgent with a 'View all (N)' link. The host should be able to scan the full Action Required tier in under 5 seconds and know exactly what needs their attention. Each item uses a consistent format: [item type icon] + [one-line description] + [deadline or urgency signal] + [primary action button].
exclude: Marketing or promotional content in the Action Required tier
Items with no deadline or consequence mixed into the urgent tier
Historical data (past leases, old reviews) in the primary view
Platform announcements that interrupt the urgency hierarchy

elements.title: Ritual Confirmation Cadence for Active Lease Anxiety Management
elements.problem: During the active lease, a stranger occupies the host's private space. Freud warns that 'civilized society is perpetually menaced with disintegration through this primary hostility of men towards one another.' The host's anxiety about the stranger does not resolve once the lease is signed -- it recurs with every stay cycle. The information architecture challenge is: what information must the platform surface between stays, and at what cadence, to provide the host with ongoing evidence that the civilizational order is holding? Without structured information delivery, the host's imagination fills the gap with anxiety. A week without a cleaning photo becomes 'the guest is not taking care of my space.' Three days without communication becomes 'something is wrong.' The absence of information is itself experienced as a threat signal. The platform must replace information voids with structured confirmation rituals.

evidence.quote: Civilized society is perpetually menaced with disintegration through this primary hostility of men towards one another... Culture has to call up every possible reinforcement in order to erect barriers against the aggressive instincts of men and hold their manifestations in check by reaction-formations in men's minds.
evidence.insight: The active lease is a sustained civilizational coexistence. The platform must erect 'barriers against the aggressive instincts' not through rules alone but through regular information rituals that confirm both parties are honoring the arrangement. Each confirmed ritual is evidence that civilization has not disintegrated.

evidence.quote: Order is a kind of repetition-compulsion by which it is ordained once for all when, where and how a thing shall be done so that on every similar occasion doubt and hesitation shall be avoided.
evidence.insight: Per-stay rituals (arrival confirmation, cleaning photos, micro-reviews) are information architecture mechanisms: they produce data at predictable intervals that the host can scan to confirm order is maintained. The cadence itself is the anxiety management tool -- not the content of any single ritual, but the reliability of the sequence.

evidence.quote: Unread proposals, pending actions, incomplete listings -- that's what a host needs to see the moment they log in.
evidence.insight: Extended to the active lease phase: what the host needs to see is the latest ritual confirmation. Did the guest confirm arrival? Were cleaning photos submitted? Is the current stay on track? The dashboard must surface this active-lease health information with the same urgency logic as proposal notifications.

elements.solution: Design a per-stay information cadence that delivers three structured confirmation signals to the host at predictable intervals within each stay cycle: (1) Arrival Confirmation: when the guest confirms arrival through the Stays Manager, the host receives a dashboard notification and (optionally) a push notification. This signals: the guest is here, on schedule, within the system. (2) Departure + Cleaning Confirmation: when the guest submits cleaning photos at departure, the host receives the photos in a scannable format (thumbnail grid, not full-size gallery requiring clicks). This signals: the guest has left, the space is maintained, the ritual was honored. (3) Per-Stay Health Summary: a brief, auto-generated summary visible on the dashboard showing the stay's status -- dates confirmed, cleaning submitted, any issues flagged. This signals: the civilizational order held for this cycle. The critical information architecture rule: if a ritual is not completed (no arrival confirmation, no cleaning photos), the platform surfaces this absence as a neutral status ('Cleaning photos not yet submitted') rather than an alarm. The host is informed without being panicked. The platform handles the follow-up with the guest, not the host.
elements.hierarchy_principle: Primary: ritual completion status (binary: confirmed/pending). Secondary: ritual content (cleaning photos, dates, review). Tertiary: historical pattern (how many stays completed, compliance rate over time). The host's first scan should answer 'is everything on track?' before they engage with any details.
elements.disclosure_pattern: Cadence-locked to the stay cycle. Each ritual appears at a predictable point in the weekly rhythm: arrival confirmation at stay start, cleaning photos at stay end, health summary within 24 hours of stay completion. The host learns the cadence and expects it, reducing the anxiety that comes from unpredictable or absent information. If the cadence is disrupted (a ritual is late), the platform notifies the host with a neutral status and a note that the platform is following up.
elements.cognitive_load_constraint: Each ritual confirmation should be absorbable in under 10 seconds. Arrival confirmation: one line ('Guest confirmed arrival for Jan 15-18'). Cleaning photos: a 4-photo thumbnail grid viewable without scrolling. Health summary: 3-4 data points (dates, cleaning status, any flags, next scheduled stay). The host should never need to open a sub-page to confirm the basic health of their active lease.
exclude: Guest communication logs unless the host requests them
Detailed financial breakdowns per stay (show cumulative earnings, not per-stay calculations)
Platform-internal compliance metrics the host cannot act on
Alerts for completed rituals that require no host action (do not notify that a review was submitted if no response is needed)

elements.title: Cumulative Civilizational Investment Narrative for Retention
elements.problem: Retention is where the host performs a retrospective cost-benefit analysis of their entire civilizational participation. Freud identifies 'the narcissism of minor differences' as the mechanism by which accumulated small grievances crystallize into a narrative of dissatisfaction. The information architecture problem is that the platform surfaces no counter-narrative. The host remembers the one bad stay, the one late payment, the one difficult guest -- but the platform does not surface the 12 good stays, the $8,000 in total earnings, the 15 positive reviews. Without a structured cumulative narrative, the host's retrospective defaults to negativity because negative experiences are more memorable than routine positive ones. Freud notes that 'civilized man has exchanged some part of his chances of happiness for a measure of security' -- but if the security is not made visible, the host remembers only the exchanged happiness.

evidence.quote: Civilized man has exchanged some part of his chances of happiness for a measure of security.
evidence.insight: At retention, the host re-evaluates this exchange. The information architecture must make the 'measure of security' tangible and cumulative: total earnings, successful stays, resolved issues, guest quality track record. If the host can see that the exchange was net-positive, the retrospective assessment favors re-listing.

evidence.quote: Pause preserves the work, keeps the door open, and costs nothing. Delete is a one-way door that creates regret.
evidence.insight: The pause principle extends to information architecture: the cumulative narrative (earnings history, review track record, hosting milestones) must persist even when a listing is paused. The host who pauses should see their full hosting history upon return, reinforcing the investment they have already made in the civilizational contract.

evidence.quote: There is an advantage, not to be undervalued, in the existence of smaller communities, through which the aggressive instinct can find an outlet in enmity towards those outside the group. It is always possible to unite considerable numbers of men in love towards one another, so long as there are still some remaining as objects for aggressive manifestations.
evidence.insight: A host who sees themselves as part of a hosting community -- with cumulative achievements, a track record, and a hosting identity -- is less likely to direct frustration at the platform. The information architecture should position the host within a community narrative, not just a transactional history.

elements.solution: Create a Hosting Summary surface that is always accessible from the dashboard and is prominently surfaced at two critical moments: (1) when a lease ends, and (2) when a paused host returns. The summary presents the host's cumulative civilizational investment in scannable form: total earnings since joining, total successful stays, average review rating received, number of guests hosted, hosting tenure (months/years). Below the summary, a timeline shows the hosting trajectory -- each lease as a segment, with earnings and review scores plotted over time. The trajectory makes the cumulative trend visible and counteracts the narcissism of minor differences by embedding any single negative experience within a larger positive pattern. At lease end, the re-listing prompt appears directly below the summary, framed as continuation ('Continue hosting') rather than a new decision ('Create new listing'). The information architecture ensures the host evaluates re-listing in the context of their full history, not in the context of the most recent experience alone.
elements.hierarchy_principle: Primary: cumulative financial return (total earnings). Secondary: cumulative social proof (reviews, ratings, successful stays). Tertiary: hosting identity signals (tenure, milestones, community membership). Financial return is primary because Freud's framework identifies the economic exchange as the foundation of civilizational participation -- the host traded autonomy for income, and the income must be visible.
elements.disclosure_pattern: Persistent and contextual. The Hosting Summary is always accessible (one click from dashboard) but is most prominently surfaced at lease-end and return-from-pause moments. At lease-end, it appears before the re-listing prompt, ensuring the host's retrospective assessment includes the full cumulative picture. At return-from-pause, it appears as the first screen, reinforcing the preserved investment. Between these moments, cumulative metrics appear as a compact widget on the dashboard's tertiary tier.
elements.cognitive_load_constraint: The summary should be readable in under 15 seconds. Five key metrics, each as a large number with a label (e.g., '$12,400 total earnings | 28 successful stays | 4.8 avg rating | 4 guests hosted | 14 months hosting'). The timeline below requires optional engagement -- the host can scan it or ignore it. No scrolling required to see all five metrics.
exclude: Negative data points (missed reviews, disputes) in the summary headline -- these belong in detailed history, not the retention-critical first scan
Comparison to other hosts (competitive framing undermines community identity)
Platform fee breakdowns in the summary view (show net earnings, not gross minus fees)
Any language that frames re-listing as a new commitment rather than a continuation
